title: QR-I Assignment 3
text:
4.

Exercise 3 We have defined for your convenience several one-input functions named f1() through f5(). Graph each of them, one at a time, on the domain -5 to 5 and, from the graph, read off the requested information. (Hint: All you need is the name of the function, you donâ€™t have to worry about how we constructed it.)

#| echo: false
#| autorun: true
f1 <- mosaicCalc::doodle_fun( ~ z, seed = 504)
f2 <- mosaicCalc::doodle_fun( ~ z, seed = 506)
f3 <- mosaicCalc::doodle_fun( ~ z, seed = 508)
f4 <- mosaicCalc::doodle_fun( ~ z, seed = 510)
f5 <- mosaicCalc::doodle_fun( ~ z, seed = 512)


#| caption: Make your plots here.
slice_plot(f1(z) ~ z, domain(z = -5:5))


For f1(), for what input does the output reach its maximum value? (Select the closest value.)


 gmc-1-lesle

   -4 Â Â Â Â Â   -3 Â Â Â Â Â   -2 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â    





For f2(), what is the input where the output crosses zero? [Pick the closest answer.]


 gmc-2-loie

   -3 Â Â Â Â Â   -1 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â    





For f3(), what is the minimum value of the output? [Pick the closest answer.]


 gmc-3-yee

   0 Â Â Â Â Â   -10 Â Â Â Â Â   -20 Â Â Â Â Â   -30 Â Â Â Â Â    





For f4(), at what input does the output cross zero? [Pick the closest answer.]


 gmc-4-rwsle

   -4 Â Â Â Â Â   -3 Â Â Â Â Â   -2 Â Â Â Â Â   0 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â    





For f5(), at how many different inputs does the output cross zero?


 gmc-5-qdr

   0 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4

title: QR-I Assignment 3
text:
4.

Exercise 4 Consider this plot of the hillside function:




#| caption: "Graphing a function"
#| autorun: true
slice_plot(hillside(z) ~ z, domain(z = -2:4))



FigureÂ 2




What R function is being used to make the plot?


 dek-1-gmek

   plot() Â Â Â Â Â   slice_plot() Â Â Â Â Â   plotfun() Â Â Â Â Â   sliceplot() Â Â Â Â Â   plot_fun() Â Â Â Â Â    





Immediately following the name of the function, there is an opening parenthesis. The matching closing parenthesis is at the very end of the command. In R (as in many computer languages) the arguments to the function are contained inside the parentheses. If there is more than one argument, successive arguments are separated by commas. How many arguments are there to slice_plot()?


 dek-2-z38d

   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â    




The first argument to slice_plot() tells which function you want to graph. In the example, the first argument is hillside(z) ~ z. This is called a â˜Â tilde expressionÂ â˜œ so named because the tilde character (~) appears.



Left
Middle
Right




hillside(z)
~ (tilde)
z




The left part of the tilde expression is a formula written in more or less conventional algebraic form. Other examples for this formula: 2*z + 3, osc(z), hillside(z) * osc(z).
The right part of the tilde expression gives the name of the input variable. In the example, the name is z, but you can use whatever name you think appropriate. Note that the formula in (i) must be written in terms of the input-variable name.
The middle part of the tilde expression is merely punctuation, but it is essential punctuation. Among other things, the tilde makes clear what are the left and right sides of the tilde expression.


Suppose that you want to call the input quantity x. You can easily modify the command to do this, just substitute x for z. In how many places do you have to make the change?


 dek-3-jwkd

   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â   4 Â Â Â Â Â    




Focus now on the graphic itselfâ€”FigureÂ 2. The name of the input variable appears as a label on the horizontal axis. The label on the vertical axis, in contrast, is just a reminder that we are plotting the output of the function versus the input quantity.
The vertical scale will be created automatically by slice_plot(), taking into account the range of function output values. But the horizontal axis is different: the user specifies this. The numerical extent of the horizontal axis is called the graphics domain.
The second argument to slice_plot() is used for the graphics domain specification.

What is the graphics domain in FigureÂ 2?


 dek-4-p3n2

   0 to 4 Â Â Â Â Â   -2 to 2 Â Â Â Â Â   -2 to 4 Â Â Â Â Â   -4 to 4 Â Â Â Â Â    




In the example, the second argument is domain(z = -2:4). The graphics domain specification will always look like this, and uses the R function domain().

How many arguments does domain() take in this example?


 dek-4-7s2r

   0 Â Â Â Â Â   1 Â Â Â Â Â   2 Â Â Â Â Â   3 Â Â Â Â Â    




There are two punctuation symbols in the argument to domain(). The colon (:) is placed between the two limits to be used for the domain. -2:4 means â€œminus 2 to 4.â€ The graphics domain zero to ten would be 0:10. The other punctuation mark is =. To the left of the = goes the name of the input variable. The expression z = -2:4 means â€œthe graphics domain of z is to be -2 to 4.

Using the â€œgraphing a functionâ€ interactive R chunk, write an expression to plot out the function osc() over the graphics domain 0 to 5. Use whatever you like as the input name. After checking that your expression works, copy the expression into the following answer block.

title: QR-I Assignment 3
text:
5.

Exercise 5 The slice_plot() produces the graph of a function with one input. Convention calls for the input to correspond to the horizontal axis and the output to the vertical axis.
For functions with two inputs, the input corresponds to the points in a two-dimensional space. That is, each possible input is a coordinate pair. To graphically represent each possible input uniquely, we need to use both the horizontal and vertical axes, one for the first input and the other for the second input. Where, then, to show the output.
Our preferred graphical format for functions of two inputs is called a â˜Â contour plotÂ â˜œ. The R chunk below shows the R/mosaic code to generate a plot. Run the chunk.

#| caption: Making a contour plot
contour_plot(    # instead of slice_plot()
  y * hill(x) ~ x & y,  # first argument
  domain(x = -2:2, y = -3:3) # second argument
  )

This R expression follows a similar form to that used for slice_plot(). Notice, however, that the tilde expression used in the first argument names both inputs: x & y on the right-hand side of the tilde. Likewise, the definition of the graphics domain involves two components, one for each of the inputs.
It takes some practice to get comfortable reading contour plots. The labels along each blue â˜Â contourÂ â˜œ specify the output for any input that lies on the contour.
In principle, each possible input point has some contour line running through it. This is the same as saying that for each input, say, (x=1, y=2), the function has an output value. But if we drew a contour for every output value, the graph would be filled with blue ink and incomprehensible. To avoid this problem, only a handful of contours are drawn. Also, to avoid cluttering up the graph with output value labels, the contour_plot() R function labels only every second contour. The output value for the unlabeled contours are half-way in-between the output values for the two labeled contours that run side-by-side with the unlabeled one.
To illustrate, the input point (x=1, y=2) falls about half-way between the contour labeled 0.6 and the unlabeled contour corresponding to output value 0.4. Since the input point is located between the 0.4 and 0.6 contours, the corresponding output will be approximately 0.5.
In this book, we wonâ€™t dwell on teaching the syntax of the contour_plot() function. When we need it, we will give you a template so that you just have to fill in the details: the names of the two inputs, the function itself, and the extent of the graphics domain along each axis.
For now, weâ€™ll practice how to read off the output for any given input. Consider FigureÂ 3, which displays a function \(f(x,y)\) we have made up for the example.








FigureÂ 3





For each of the five distinct input points labeled (a) to (e), give a good estimate of the corresponding output.

title: One-minute questions
text:
After each class session, you are expected to give a brief summary of what happened in that session as well as pointing to things that either 1) were particularly meaningful to you or 2) that you found confusing.
These are called one-minute questions to indicate roughly how much time you should spend on your answer. Of course, you are welcome to spend more time. But even if you spend just one minute, your answer should be honest, articulate, and aimed at improving the class for yourself and your student colleagues.
DO NOT write your answer while still in class.


One-minute questions

title: About
text:
At the University of Austin, our students pursue a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Studies. As part of their required course of study, students must complete a core curriculum called the Intellectual Foundations, which consists of 15 intensive courses that introduce students to the various languages of understanding and teach them to see things whole. As part of this sequence, students are challenged to confront timeless questions beginning in antiquity and culminating in the present day.
There are two quantitative reasoning courses in the Intellectual Foundation curriculum. These are:

Quantitative Reasoning I (â€œQR â€” Analysisâ€), which teaches students the mathematical modeling tools useful for modelling real-world phenomena.
Quantitative Reasoning II (â€œQR â€” Dataâ€), which teaches students to extract useful information from data using modern data science techniques.

Both QR â€” Analysis and QR â€” Data are unlike the introductory courses found at almost all other colleges and universities. We have selected topics based on their utility in modern professional work. In contrast, basic topics in the traditional curriculum reflect the historical development of mathematics rather than the needs of modern work. Modern topics widely used in the economy and scientific/technical worlds are relegated to so-called â€œadvancedâ€ courses far downstream where they are inaccessible to almost all students.
Our two QR courses dramatically streamline the pre-requisites for successful work with modern quantitative topics. Surprisingly often the â€œadvancedâ€ topics are readily accessible to students, so long as one is willing to move beyond traditional pedagogy and avoid unwarranted devotion to topics that were important historically but are no longer necessarily for understanding.

NoteChap 1: Models






Exercise W1. 1 Many people experience the symptoms of a housing shortage: splitting up apartments to accomodate roommate groups; financial stress due (in part) to high rents; deferring life decisions such as having children; living in deteriorating, aging buildings, and so on.
Weâ€™re used to thinking about people in terms of lifespan, but it is also useful to think about buildings that way. City and local governments keep detailed information about the housing stock, largely for tax purposes. Services like <zillow.com> have data readily available to the public.
Question: What about the houses listed on Zillow might presented a view biased to houses in better condition?


A life-cycle assessment of a sample of US houses and apartments by Aktas and Bilic (2012) produced the following graphic about how long houses and apartments remain habitable.






Figure W1.Â 1: â€œLifetime distribution of residential buildings calculated from multiple American Housing Survey microdata,â€ from Aktas and Bilic 2012.



Question: Is the graph consistent with the claim that 7% of US housing stock was built before 1920?


Question: Speculate on what might account for the rightward shift of the curve over the ten year period considered. Consider these two hypotheses:

house building techniques have been improving. (When would they have had to improve to produce the curve shift?)
the current housing shortage has resulted in buildings being used after the time that they would have been replaced were there no housing shortage?







Exercise W1. 2 Consider this simple, made-up mortality table that might be representative of a bird species, e.g.Â robins.



Age
Mortality
Starting Population




0

1000


1
0.50
500

0.50
250


3
1.00
125


4

0



Calculate the life expectancy for these birds. Give a number, but also explain you reasoning in words. (Hint: Itâ€™s not a long calculation.)





Exercise W1. 3 Short classroom discussion about the SIR model graphic including:

a quick demonstration (narrated by the students) of the patterns seen for different settings of the parameters.
speculate on how to operationalize â€œsocial distance.â€
reason why the isolation parameter only goes up to 50%: the behavior doesnâ€™t change much for higher isolations. Explain that % for isolation means the fraction of the infectives who isolate or, equivalently, how much of the time infectives isolate.












NoteChap 2: Quantities and what else





Is there something here?

title: Student responsibilities
text: Student responsibilities

title: UATX Quantitative Reasoning - Analysis
text:
This is the course homepage for UATX INF 1130 (Quantitative Reasoning I). All course materials can be found through this website, and information will be updated throughout the term. This site is designed for students, but visitors are welcome. General information for visitors is available via the About page.
A typical class week consists of one or two of the topics from the textbook and includes textbook readings, homework questions, and a short weekly quiz.

title: Weekly Materials
text:
CautionDevelopment Note:





This is where we will list the readings, assignments, quiz days, and other components for each class session. The formatting is subject to change.



This page provides an archive of the topics, class materials, and homework assignments used in the course. This page is kept up-to-date throughout the term.







CautionRemember to hand in your work!





Much of your work for the class will take the form of completing interactive web documents. Near the top of each such document, there is a highlighted box very similar to this on. To hand in your work, open that box and press â€œCollect your answersâ€. This will copy your essay and multiple-choice answers to your clipboard, in preparation for uploading them to the courseâ€™s collection site.
After pressing **â€œCollect your answersâ€* to the the follow the link to upload site. This leads to a Google form providing space for your email address and for pasting your answers from the clipboard. The same link will be used for the entire course.
Finally, press the â€œSubmitâ€ button on the Google form. Done!






TipMore details about the submission process â€¦





Please do not edit the clipboard string. Itâ€™s intended for computer-to-computer communication and will look something like this.
{"docid":"One-minute.rmarkdown","MC":[],"Essays":[{"itemid":"1-min-week1-a","contents":"The class was great!"},{"itemid":"1-min-week1-b","contents":"Even better today!"}}
There may be many empty fields in the string; that is as it should be.
So long as you are using the same browser on the same computer, your answers will continue to appear in the web document each time you open it. (DONâ€™T CONFUSE THIS with submitting your work. For us to receive it, it has to be submitted via the Google form.) You can go back to the web document whenever you like. So feel free to do your work in stages, perhaps spread over a couple of days.
When in doubt whether your work has been submitted, submit it again! The computerized collection system will take care of any duplications.












NoteEvery week






One-minute essays. These should be submitted by end of day (11:59 PM) after every class meeting.
A Quiz will be given once per week at the first class meeting of that week. Usually this is Monday (for section 001) or Tuesday (for sections 003 & 004).Quizzes will be short (under 10 minutes) and delivered in-class.







Reading: Chapters 1 and 2 of the QR-A textbook. Answer the Reading Questions for Chap-1 & Chap-2. In later weeks you will be asked to submit these before your class session.







TipAssignment 1






Link to assignment document
Quiz: Mon Jan 12 or Tues Jan 13. Note that this is before the submission deadline.
Submission deadline: Start of your class Wed Jan 14 or Thurs Jan 15.









Quiz covering Week 1 material in your Mon/Tues class.

Wed/Thurs Reading: Chapter 4 of QR-A. Answer and submit the Reading Questions before your class meeting.

text:

Link to upload site

If the answers that have been loaded automatically are not yours, press this button before starting your work:


Clear memory













NoteDrill for Chapter 3





Open drill questions in this document
Remember to submit your drill answers through that document. But for the exercises in the present document, use the â€œcollect answersâ€ at the top of this page.









NoteChapter Three






1.2.



Exercise 1 The following is from the Atlantic magazine article, â€œScience Is Winning the Tour de Franceâ€ (by Matt Seaton, July 25, 2025)

The gold standard of cycling performanceâ€”which boils down to a riderâ€™s ability to push against the wind and go uphill fastâ€”is a high power-to-weight ratio, given in watts per kilogram. The benchmark figure is how many watts per kilo a cyclist can sustain for a one-hour effort. Every rider now has a power meter fitted to their bike, so they know their numbers in a constant, real-time way (together with heart rate, speed, and other measurements).

The article describes the then-current leader in the Tour de France as having a power-to-weight ratio of seven watts per kilogram.

If this rider weighs 70 kg, how many watts can he generate?


 sbk-1-vsw

   49 watts Â Â Â Â Â   70 watts Â Â Â Â Â   490 watts Â Â Â Â Â   700 watts Â Â Â Â Â    





Look up the conversion factor from watts to horsepower. How many horsepower is the rider generating?


 sbk-2-ie2d

   0.066 hp Â Â Â Â Â   0.660 hp Â Â Â Â Â   6.60 hp Â Â Â Â Â   66.0 hp Â Â Â Â Â    





A horse weighing 500 kg can generate one horsepower while walking. How does the horseâ€™s power efficiency per weight compare to the champion bike rider.


 sbk-3-r7f


 Horse 7 W/kg versus human 1.4 W/kg


 Human 7 W/kg versus horse 1.4 W/kg


 Human 7 W/kg versus horse 2.8 W/kg


 Horse 70 W/kg versus human 280 W/kg







There is no conversion factor from watts to calories. Why not?


 sbk-4-ri3


 One is metric units, the other is â€œtraditionalâ€ units.


 You canâ€™t compare light-bulbs to food!


 They have different dimensions.


 Thatâ€™s wrong. There is a conversion factor.







Look up the conversion factor from watt-seconds to kilo-calories (kcal (or â€œCalâ€), the relevant unit when looking at diet). How many kcal does the rider produce when biking for one hour at 7 w/kg?


 sbk-5-nsl2

   211 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   422 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   633 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   844 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   1688 kcal Â Â Â Â Â    




1 watt-second is 0.000239006 kcal. In an hour, the rider generates 3600 s times 70 kg times 7 w/kg = 422 kcal

Itâ€™s estimated that a personâ€™s efficiency when converting dietary calories to work/movement calories is about 25%. In an hour of biking at 7 w/kg, how many dietary calories does a 70-kg rider consume?


 sbk-6-fjfk

   211 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   422 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   633 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   844 kcal Â Â Â Â Â   1688 kcal Â Â Â Â Â    





An â€œaverageâ€ adult walking at 2.5 mi/hr is said to use about 150 watts of power. For this hypothetical adult, how much energy is consumed in a 1-hour walk?


 sbk-7-fjfk

   130 Cal Â Â Â Â Â   260 Cal Â Â Â Â Â   1.5 Wh Â Â Â Â Â   15 Wh Â Â Â Â Â
